data.title: Images are never reloaded
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.4.0 (6276dcb0ae497766056b4c09ea75be1d76a8b679, 2016-08-04T16:41:29.513Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 15.6.0

Steps to Reproduce:
1. New Directory
2. run code .
3. Place an PNG file as picture.png in that directory
4. View It with VS Code (using explorer): File displays correctly
   5.Delete the file with the  explorer
5. Place a different PNG File with the same name as picture.png in directory
6. View with explorer: The first image is displayed. (Expected the new image)

data.title: Restore cursor position for readonly files

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.4.0
- OS Version: Windows 10/64
### Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open two or more files in an editor group.
2. In one of the opened files scroll down a number of lines.
3. Press `CTRL+TAB` multiple times until the editor group revolves to the original file.

=> You will notice that the previous cursor position was lost and that the cursor has moved to the first column in the first line of the file.
### Suggested behaviour:

The cursor position for each opened file in the editor should be retained.

---

PS: I'd like to propose an option to have `CTRL+TAB` not only cycle through opened files within a _single_ editor group but through _all_ files in _all_ editor groups. This would reflect common Microsoft style guide and program behaviour and would increase daily VS Code usability.

data.title: Extension dev/debug: using vscode.workspace.findFiles

data.title: Feature: Ability to save regex Find/Replace patterns for future use
data.body:
### Feature Request
- VSCode Version:
  Version 1.4.0 (1.4.0)
- OS Version:
  OS X El Capitan 10.11.6 (15G31)

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open a text document in vscode with a fair amount of text. 
2. Launch the Find/Replace dialogue "Command + F" 
3. Click the regex icon to enter a regex pattern for the find and replace forms. 
4. Observe there is no means from that dialogue to save the regex pattern or reference previously used regex patterns. 

Expected Behavior: 
1. The Find/Replace dialogue would provide a means of saving regex patterns used for future use. Please see attached screen shots of the method BBEdit uses to accomplish this as an example of this feature. 
![screenshot_1315](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/15255373/17853055/539c3e3a-681f-11e6-8d74-efb1f0b77bb5.png)

data.title: Markdown should handle GFM links with parenthesis/special chars in URL
data.body:
- VSCode Version:
  Version 1.4.0 (1.4.0)
- OS Version:
  OSX El Capitan 10.11.6 (15G31)
  Steps to Reproduce:
1. Create or open a Markdown document in vscode with the .md extension. 
2. Open the vscode Markdown Preview window for live previewing.  ⇧⌘V
3. Add the following markdown formatted link and header text to the document. 

```
# This is a markdown formatting test
Here is a link 
[TestLink](https://console.aws.amazon.com/cloudwatch/home?region=us-east-1#metrics:graph=~(metrics~(~(~'AWS*2fEC2~'CPUUtilization~'AutoScalingGroupName~'asg-prod-test)~(~'.~'NetworkIn~'.~'.~(yAxis~'right))~(~'.~'NetworkOut~'.~'.)~(~'AWS*2fLogs~'IncomingBytes~'LogGroupName~'TEST_Proxy)~(~'.~'IncomingLogEvents~'.~'.)~(~'AWS*2fEC2~'CPUUtilization~'AutoScalingGroupName~'asg-test-markdown-instance)~(~'.~'NetworkIn~'.~'.~(yAxis~'right))~(~'.~'NetworkOut~'.~'.)~(~'.~'CPUUtilization~'.~'asg-test-markdown-instance)~(~'.~'NetworkIn~'.~'.~(yAxis~'right))~(~'.~'NetworkOut~'.~'.)~(~'AWS*2fLogs~'IncomingBytes~'LogGroupName~'test-markdown-vpc-flow-logs)~(~'.~'IncomingLogEvents~'.~'.))~period~60~stat~'Average~start~'2016-08-17T04*3a00*3a00Z~end~'2016-08-17T07*3a01*3a59Z~yAxis~(left~null~right~null)~region~'us-east-1))

```
1. Observe the link is not formatted or displayed correctly. The complex assortment of characters specifically parenthesis and tilda seem to prevent the parser from properly recognizing the link. 
2. Perform the same the test using [BBEdit](http://www.barebones.com/products/bbedit/) and [Github Markdown Preview Package](https://github.com/gavinaiken/bbedit-scripts) 
3.  Observe the link is properly formatted in the preview window. 

**Please see attached screen shots for side by sides of preview examples** 
![vscode-markdown-preview-defect](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/15255373/17852545/be82b10a-681c-11e6-9b75-c0ed34de662e.png)
![bbedit-markdown-preview-plugin](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/15255373/17852551/c6299b08-681c-11e6-84b5-31ef45254d63.png)

data.title: Feature Request: File Outline View for TypeScript
data.body:
It would be very useful to have a structural outline of the currently opened TypeScript file in VScode.

For an example of what I mean, check out this screenshot of an outline from a Java file in Eclipse:

![outline](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/16356998/16942947/4c382adc-4d99-11e6-8703-a8a64a1ca62d.png)

It displays the names of all types on top-level, and folded within them are the names of all fields and methods, including their names as well as parameter and return types. Clicking on a member in the outline jumps to the declaration. The icons indicate if the method is public (green) or protected (yellow).

As somebody who used Eclipse extensively in the past, I find it very difficult to program without such a view.

data.title: Windows: Code should run as same user after updating

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.1.1
- OS Version: Windows 7, 64-bit

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Be on an annoying corporate network where the standard admin account doesn't work, but you have another "local admin" account that does.
2. Install VS Code using the local admin account.
3. Run it as a non-admin user.
4. Try to install an extension.
5. Observe the message "Visual Studio Code will be update after it restarts"
6. Click "Update Now"
7. VSC restarts but shows a dialog "You must be logged in as an administrator when installing this program."
8. Run VSC as the local admin account ("Run as different user"; not "Run as administrator").
9. Try to install the extension again
10. This time it works, but it only installed it for the local admin account, not for my standard account.
11. Run VSC as a non-admin user.
12. Extension is not installed.

data.title: [Feature Request] IntelliJ-style git gutter patch preview/operations (git checkout -p)

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
IntelliJ has a very natural UI for managing individual git patches - click in the gutter at a change indicator, and you immediately have the previous version of the file displayed and options for that diff (by far the most useful of which is rollback)

![intellij_git_gutter](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1312873/17848825/86bd607c-684d-11e6-86d6-f8964bd422f4.gif)
### Use case

You open back up your editor and look at the file you were working on last night. You see in the sidebar little symbols indicating additions removals and changes (handy!). You can't remember _what_ this particular change was though.
#### IntelliJ solution

Click the gutter symbol, see the old version of these few lines _immediately in context_. Ohh yeah that was just something you were fooling around with for debugging but it's not needed any more, click to rollback this single change.
#### VSCode solution

Change entirely to another view in the editor to see a full file-by-file diff of the two files (_Git: Open Change_). Unless I'm mistaken, manually change the file to undo the change (I looked for _Git: {Revert,Undo,Rollback} this {change,diff,patch}_) but came up empty).
### Big picture

VSCode's inbuilt git UI is great for rolling back changes at the file level (`git checkout`), but weak at changes at the patch level (`git checkout -p`). This IntelliJ paradigm is the best GUI I have seen for handling this common operation.

I would love to contribute this feature to VSCode, whether though an extension or an addition to the core product. I would personally lobby for an inclusion in the core, as it complements and completes in my mind the existing git checkout/add features that do not require extensions. I also believe it is not presently possible to customise the gutter in extensions (https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/9561).

data.title: After debug (of extension) file is not editable
data.body:
- VSCode Version: insiders
- OS Version: windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

I start debugging extension. After debug is stopped. I can not fully edit extensions code some commands (keys) like backspace don't work, can insert and add content, but can not remove it.

I have to do `Ctrl+P` and type file name and "activate" it - then edit mode fixes.

Not sure if it happens only while extensions debug.

data.title: Uri#fsPath should be empty when there is no path but just an authority
data.body: We see authority-only uris for which `fsPath` works (but is broken since the casing has changed). See #9876

data.title: Tag translation/20160817.01 breaks npm installation

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.4.0
- OS Version: Windows 10

npm install vscode --save-dev 

The installation of vscode as a dependency seems to be broken because of the new tag translation/20160817.01. The script "node ./node_modules/vscode/bin/install" fetches all tags from the repository and parses them via semver. This operation fails because 20160817.01 is not a valid semver.

- OS Version:

1. Open a directory with lots of files
2. Scroll down a bit in the explorer pane
3. hold click a file to start a move operation

The explorer window will scroll up by one file and you will be dragging the file above the one you wanted to select

data.title: [decorators] Decoration types break each other
What URLs does Code use for updates/extensions?
data.body:
Can you provide what URLs VS Code uses to poll for updates and extensions in the Marketplace? 

Like others, am getting the self-signed cert error but wish to understand the URLs/FQDNs in use so I can exclude them from the SSL Decryption as oppose to toggling the ssl proxy setting in Code.

data.title: Moving Lines/Blocks Using ALT+Up/Down Arrow Combo Locks Up VS Code
data.body:
-VSCode Version: 1.4
-OS Version: 14905.rs_prerelease.160811-1739

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Move a line/block up/down the page multiple lines, say a quarter to half a screen's worth, with ALT+Up/Down Arrow and VS Code locks up.

Cut/Paste is fine, but trying to move location by too many lines with the ALT combo locks up the application and it must be shutdown via the Task Manager.

data.title: Large JS/JSON Files Lock Up VS Code

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.4
- OS Version: 14905.rs_prerelease.160811-1739

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Drop in a large JS/JSON file, say a large array of objects.

VS Code can't process such a file and locks up. Also tested in Sublime 3 and there were no issues with the same data set, was able to move around the file with no problem.
